epigraphs.text: The most dangerous moment is not the coup, but the day when everyone behaves as if it already succeeded.
Institutions are not ruined in a single blow; they are worn down by a thousand uses for purposes they were never meant to serve.
When hunger, fear, and spectacle become instruments of policy, the line between government and domination has already been crossed.

image_prompts.square: A 1:1 symbolic still life: a worn government-issue lunch tray holding a snapped food stamp card, an unsigned pardon document, and a small model drone, all resting on a marble slab carved like a presidential seal. Behind them, a miniature crystal chandelier and ballroom column rise from the ruins of a crumbling file folder stamped "SNAP" and "Court Orders." A brass desk clock frozen at 8:11 sits to the side. Painterly realism, strong contrasts, no text.
image_prompts.wide: A dusk-lit 16:9 scene of the White House East Wing partially demolished and wrapped in scaffolding, a gleaming, half-built ballroom rising where historic walls once stood. In the foreground, a long line of people in work uniforms and winter coats wait outside a closed federal building marked by a simple seal, clutching empty grocery bags. Military helicopters and distant searchlights hover over a hazy city skyline, while a large, old-fashioned clock in the sky reads just past 8:11, its minute hand nudged closer to midnight. The mood is painterly, realistic, and tense, with rich shadows and muted patriotic colors.

long_synopsis: In Week 41 of Trump’s second term, the Democracy Clock inched only 0.3 minutes closer to midnight, remaining at 8:11 p.m., but the apparent stillness masked consolidation. A fourth week of government shutdown became a governing method: SNAP reserves were withheld, guidance scrubbed, and partisan banners blamed a “Radical Left Democrat shutdown” while 42 million people faced food insecurity and federal workers labored unpaid. The same crisis justified purging CDC staff and closing its congressional liaison office, hollowing public health oversight. Immigration and security tools were repurposed for domestic control: ICE leadership was replaced with Border Patrol hardliners, raids with helicopters and tear gas swept cities, secret detentions expanded, and visas were revoked for critics as refugee policy was recast along racial and ideological lines. Simultaneously, pardons, defense contracts, and a donor-funded White House ballroom fused public authority with Trump family and donor wealth. Courts, unions, state officials, and civil-rights lawyers mounted notable but fragmented resistance, slowing some abuses without altering the trajectory.
